column1: Gdynia ( gə-DIN-ee-ə; Polish: [ˈɡdɨɲa] (listen); German: Gdingen; Kashubian: Gdiniô
column2: 1939-1945 Gotenhafen) is a city in northern Poland. Located on Gdańsk Bay on the southern coast of the Baltic Sea
column3: it is a  major seaport and the second-largest city in Pomeranian Voivodeship after Gdańsk. Gdynia has a population of 246
column5: which makes it the twelfth-largest city in Poland. It is part of a conurbation with the spa town of Sopot
column8: which together form a metropolitan area called the Tricity (Trójmiasto)

column1: Historically and culturally part of Kashubia in Eastern Pomerania
column2: Gdynia for centuries remained a small farming and fishing village. At the beginning of the 20th-century
column3: Gdynia attracted visitors as a seaside resort town
column4: and began to build tourism. The local population increased in response to the change in the economy.

column1: After Poland regained its independence in 1918
column2: the government decided to construct a Polish seaport in Gdynia
column3: between the Free City of Danzig (a semi-autonomous city-state) and German Pomerania
column4: making Gdynia a primary economic hub. In 1926 Gdynia was granted city rights
column5: after which it enjoyed a rapid demographic and architectural development.

column1: This was interrupted by the outbreak of World War II
column2: during which the newly built port and shipyard were completely destroyed. The population of the city suffered heavy losses
column3: as most of the inhabitants were evicted and expelled by the German occupiers. The locals were either displaced to other regions of occupied Poland or sent to German Nazi concentration camps throughout Europe.

column2: Gdynia was settled with the former inhabitants of Warsaw
column5: such as Lviv and Vilnius in the Eastern Borderlands. The city was gradually regenerating
column6: with its shipyard being rebuilt and expanded. In December 1970 the shipyard workers' protest against an increase in government-established prices was violently repressed by government forces. This greatly contributed to the rise of the Solidarity movement in nearby Gdańsk.

column1: Today the port of Gdynia is a regular stopover on the cruising itinerary of large
column2: luxury passenger ships. A new ferry terminal with a civil airport are under development. The city has won numerous awards for its safety
column5: and a rich variety of tourist attractions. In 2013 Gdynia was ranked by readers of The News as Poland's best city to live in
column6: and topped the national rankings in the category of "general quality of life".

column1: The area of the later city of Gdynia shared its history with Pomerelia (Eastern Pomerania). In prehistoric times
column2: it was the center of Oksywie culture; it was later populated by Slavs with some Baltic Prussian influences.

column1: Late 10th century: Pomerelia was united with Poland.
During the reign of Mieszko II
column2: Pomerelia seceded from Poland and became independent.

column1: 1116/1121: Bolesław III reunited Pomerelia with Poland.
1209: First mention of Oxhöft (now known as Oksywie
column2: which is now a part of Gdynia).

column1: 1227: Pomerelia again became an independent Duchy.
1253: First known mention of the name "Gdynia"
column2: as a Pomeranian (Kashubian) fishing village. The first church on this part of the Baltic Sea coast was built there.

column1: 1294: Pomerelia was inherited by the future Polish king Przemysł II

column1: 1466: Thirteen Years' War ended. Pomerelia became part of Royal Prussia
column2: a newly established province of the Kingdom of Poland

column1: 1772: In the First Partition of Poland
column2: Royal Prussia (including Gdynia) was annexed into the Kingdom of Prussia. Gdynia became known in German as Gdingen
column3: and was expropriated from the Cistercian Order.

column1: 1789: There were only 21 houses in Gdynia. Around that time Gdynia (Gdingen) was so small that it was not marked on many maps of the period: it was about halfway from Oxhöft to Kleine Katz.
The Kingdom of Prussia became part of the German Empire.
The village of Gdingen had some 1
column2: 200 inhabitants. At the time it was not a poor fishing village as it is sometimes described; it had become a popular tourist spot with several guest houses
column5: several brick houses and a small harbour with a pier for small trading ships. The first Kashubian mayor of Gdingen was Jan Radtke.

column1: 1905: Gdingen shown on a big map
column2: on the coast between Oxhöft and Zoppot.

column1: 1919: Treaty of Versailles and the start of the dismemberment of eastern Germany.

column2: along with other parts of former West Prussia
column3: became a part of the new Republic of Poland; simultaneously
column4: the city of Danzig and surrounding area was declared a free city and put under the League of Nations
column5: though Poland was given economic liberties and requisitioned for matters of foreign representation.

column1: The decision to build a major seaport at Gdynia village was made by the Polish government in winter 1920
column2: in the midst of the Polish–Soviet War (1919–1920). The authorities and seaport workers of the Free City of Danzig felt Poland's economic rights in the city were being misappropriated to help fight the war. German dockworkers went on strike
column3: refusing to unload shipments of military supplies sent from the West to aid the Polish army
column4: and Poland realized the need for a port city it was in complete control of
column5: economically and politically.

column1: Construction of Gdynia seaport started in 1921 but
column2: because of financial difficulties
column3: it was conducted slowly and with interruptions. It was accelerated after the Sejm (Polish parliament) passed the Gdynia Seaport Construction Act on 23 September 1922. By 1923 a 550-metre pier
column4: 175 metres (574 feet) of a wooden tide breaker
column5: and a small harbour had been constructed. Ceremonial inauguration of Gdynia as a temporary military port and fishers' shelter took place on 23 April 1923. The first major seagoing ship arrived on 13 August 1923.

column1: To speed up the construction works
column2: the Polish government in November 1924 signed a contract with the French-Polish Consortium for Gdynia Seaport Construction. By the end of 1925
column3: they had built a small seven-metre-deep harbour
column5: part of the north pier
column7: and had ordered the trans-shipment equipment. The works were going more slowly than expected
column8: however. They accelerated only after May 1926
column9: because of an increase in Polish exports by sea
column11: the outbreak of the German–Polish trade war which reverted most Polish international trade to sea routes
column12: and thanks to the personal engagement of Eugeniusz Kwiatkowski
column13: Polish Minister of Industry and Trade (also responsible for the construction of Centralny Okręg Przemysłowy). By the end of 1930 docks
column16: and many auxiliary and industrial installations were constructed (such as depots
column18: and a rice processing factory) or started (such as a large cold store).

column4: 000 tons (1929). At this time Gdynia was the only transit and special seaport designed for coal exports.

column1: In the years 1931–1939 Gdynia harbour was further extended to become a universal seaport. In 1938 Gdynia was the largest and most modern seaport on the Baltic Sea
column2: as well as the tenth biggest in Europe. The trans-shipments rose to 8.7 million tons
column3: which was 46% of Polish foreign trade. In 1938 the Gdynia shipyard started to build its first full-sea ship

column1: The city was constructed later than the seaport. In 1925 a special committee was inaugurated to build the city; city expansion plans were designed and city rights were granted in 1926
column2: and tax privileges were granted for investors in 1927. The city started to grow significantly after 1928.

column1: A new railway station and the Post Office were completed. The State railways extended their lines
column2: built bridges and also constructed a group of houses for their employees. Within a few years houses were built along some 10 miles (16 km) of road leading northward from the Free City of Danzig to Gdynia and beyond. Public institutions and private employers helped their staffs to build houses.

column1: In 1933 a plan of development providing for a population of 250
column2: 000 was worked out by a special commission appointed by a government committee
column3: in collaboration with the municipal authorities. By 1939 the population had grown to over 120

column1: The city and seaport were occupied in September 1939 by German troops and renamed Gotenhafen after the Goths
column2: an ancient Germanic tribe
column3: who had lived in the area. Some 50
column5: who after 1920 had been brought into the area by the Polish government after the decision to enlarge the harbour was made
column6: were expelled to the General Government. Kashubians who were suspected to support the Polish cause
column8: were arrested and executed. The main place of execution was Piaśnica (Groß Plaßnitz)
column10: 000 were executed. The German gauleiter Albert Forster considered Kashubians of "low value" and did not support any attempts to create a Kashubian nationality. Some Kashubians organized anti-Nazi resistance groups
column12: and the exiled "Zwiazek Pomorski" in Great Britain.

column1: The harbour was transformed into a German naval base. The shipyard was expanded in 1940 and became a branch of the Kiel shipyard (Deutsche Werke Kiel A.G.). Gotenhafen became an important base
column2: due to its being relatively distant from the war theater
column3: and many German large ships—battleships and heavy cruisers—were anchored there. During 1942
column4: Dr Joseph Goebbels authorized relocation of Cap Arcona to Gotenhafen Harbour as a stand-in for RMS Titanic during filming of the German-produced movie Titanic
column5: directed by Herbert Selpin.

column1: The city was also the location of the Nazi Gotenhafen subcamp of the Stutthof concentration camp.
The seaport and the shipyard both witnessed several air raids by the Allies from 1943 onwards
column2: but suffered little damage. Gotenhafen was used during winter 1944–45 to evacuate German troops and refugees trapped by the Red Army. Some of the ships were hit by torpedoes from Soviet submarines in the Baltic Sea on the route west. The ship Wilhelm Gustloff sank
column4: 400 people with her – the worst loss of life in a single sinking in maritime history. The seaport area was largely destroyed by withdrawing German troops and millions of encircled refugees in 1945 being bombarded by the Soviet military (90% of the buildings and equipment were destroyed) and the harbour entrance was blocked by the German battleship Gneisenau that had been brought to Gotenhafen for major repairs.

column3: Gotenhafen was captured by the Soviets and assigned to Polish Gdańsk Voivodeship
column4: who again renamed it Gdynia.In the Polish 1970 protests
column5: worker demonstrations took place at Gdynia Shipyard. Workers were fired upon by the police. The fallen (e.g. Brunon Drywa) became symbolized by a fictitious worker Janek Wiśniewski
column6: commemorated in a song by Mieczysław Cholewa

column1: One of Gdynia's important streets is named after Janek Wiśniewski. The same person was portrayed by Andrzej Wajda in his movie Man of Iron as Mateusz Birkut.

column1: The climate of Gdynia is an oceanic climate owing to its position of the Baltic Sea
column2: which moderates the temperatures
column3: compared to the interior of Poland. The climate is cool throughout the year and there is a somewhat uniform precipitation throughout the year. Typical of Northern Europe
column4: there is little sunshine during the year.

column1: Gdynia is a relatively modern city. Its architecture includes the 13th century St. Michael the Archangel's Church in Oksywie
column2: the oldest building in Gdynia
column3: and the 17th century neo-Gothic manor house located on Folwarczna Street in Orłowo. The city also holds many examples of early 20th-century architecture
column5: and modernism. A good example of modernism is PLO building situated at 10 Lutego Street.

column1: The surrounding hills and the coastline attract many nature lovers. A leisure pier and a cliff-like coastline in Kępa Redłowska
column2: as well as the surrounding Nature Reserve
column3: are also popular locations. In the harbour
column4: there are two anchored museum ships
column5: the destroyer ORP Błyskawica and the tall ship frigate Dar Pomorza. A 1.5-kilometre (0.93 mi)-long promenade leads from the marina in the city center
column6: to the beach in Redłowo.Most of Gdynia can be seen from Kamienna Góra (54 metres (177 feet) asl) or the viewing point near Chwaszczyno. There are also two viewing towers
